text.0: ho there my consort stay thou fiercesouled lady and let us reason for a while together.
text.1: such thoughts as these of ours while yet unspoken in days gone by have never brought us comfort.
text.2: what am i now to do with this thy saying i have gone from thee like the first of mornings.
text.3: purūravas return thou to thy dwelling i like the wind am difficult to capture.
text.4: like a shaft sent for glory from the quiver or swiftsteed winning cattle winning hundreds.
text.5: the lightning seemed to flash as cowards planned it the minstrels bleated like a lamb in trouble.
text.6: giving her husbands father life and riches from the near dwelling when her lover craved her.
text.7: she sought the home wherein she found her pleasure accepting day and night her lords embraces.
text.8: thrice in the day didst thou embrace thy consort though coldly she received thy fond caresses.
text.9: to thy desires purūravas i yielded so wast thou king o hero of my body.
text.10: the maids sujirni sreni sumneapi charanyu granthini and hradecaksus.
text.11: these like red kine have hastened forth the bright ones and like milchcows have lowed in emulation.
text.12: while he was born the dames sate down together the rivers with free kindness gave him nurture.
text.13: and then purūravas the gods increased thee for mighty battle to destroy the dasyus.
text.14: when i a mortal wooed to mine embraces these heavenly nymphs who laid aside their raiment.
text.15: like a scared snake they fled from me in terror like chariot horses when the car has touched them.
text.16: when loving these immortal ones the mortal hath converse with the nymphs as they allow him.
text.17: like swans they show the beauty of their bodies like horses in their play they bite and nibble.
text.18: she who flashed brilliant as the falling lightning brought me delicious presents from the waters.
text.19: now from the flood be born a strong young hero may uruvasi prolong her life for ever.
text.20: thy birth hath made me drink from earthly milchkine this power purūravas hast thou vouchsafed me.
text.21: i knew and warned thee on that day thou wouldst not hear me what sayest thou when naught avails thee.
text.22: when will the son be born and seek his father mournerlike will he weep when first he knows him.
text.23: who shall divide the accordant wife and husband while fire is shining with thy consorts parents.
text.24: i will console him when his tears are falling he shall not weep and cry for care that blesses.
text.25: that which is thine between us will i send thee go home again thou foolṭhou hast not won me.
text.26: thy lover shall flee forth this day for ever to seek without return the farthest distance.
text.27: then let his bed be in destructions bosom and there let fierce rapacious wolves devour him.
text.28: nay do not die purūravas nor vanish let not the evilomened wolves devour thee.
text.29: with women there can be no lasting friendship hearts of hyenas are the hearts of women.
text.30: when amid men in altered shape i sojourned and through four autumns spent the nights among them.
text.31: i tasted once a day a drop of butter and even now with that am i am contented.
text.32: i her best love call urvasi to meet me her who fills air and measures out the region.
text.33: let the gift brought by piety approach thee turn thou to me again my heart is troubled.
text.34: thus speak these gods to thee o son of iḷā as death hath verily got thee for his subject.
text.35: thy sons shall serve the gods with their oblation and thou moreover shalt rejoice in svarga.
